segments.text: Another area of research that has been done here and reported in several places, including one of the
held in Brazil, and two years ago, almost two years ago, at the first Latin American Polity Congress, which was held in Mexico City, this subject was reported.
But it is a very popular area of concern
among institutional as well as industry people at the present time, and that is the so-called recycling of poultry wastes.
And we did some work on this, actually recycling it to

In the poultry, the most common usage of the recycling of the nutrients and the actual feed wastage from the troughs and also the undigested material going through the birds, you see, plus what little they can get from the litter that they use for growing the birds.
They call this...
DPW, dried poultry waste, and it has been used rather extensively for feeding of cattle.
It is still frowned upon, its use is still frowned upon by the FDA because they are afraid of a
additives that may still be in the material and thus pick it up as residues in the tissues.
But the people, the industry people, are very careful about this and they normally do not use it if there's any possibility of contamination of the tissues of animals.
But in 1969, we published, that's five years ago, we published an article which covered two years of work with laying hens where we recycled this.
litter from three different sources, from the broilers and from laying hens and from pullets that had been raised to laying age.
And these three sources of the DPW, or dried poultry waste, and we used this and used it at 10 and 20 percent levels and got very good results.
It can be reused.
In other words, we only reused it one time, but it probably could be recycled again and again, particularly if it's used with cattle, I'm quite sure, that can be reused.
And so we think we were fairly early in our interest in this area and actually did some experimental work in this area.
I've noted that a large percentage of the work that you have done on chickens has been with laying hens.
How did you come to settle upon laying hens as opposed to broilers or some other aspect?
Well, that's a very good question, and it has perhaps a surprising answer, but not necessarily so.
You will recall that when I entered the poultry department at Texas A&M University, I entered it as head of the department in an administrative position.
And so we were affected in the same way that almost all institutions are.
You never have enough financial support to do all of the things that you and your staff want to do.
So you have to sort of set up priorities and use your funds in this fashion.
Well, this being true, you see, that there is...
rarely, if ever, enough funds to do all the things that a scientific staff wants to do.
It was quite important, being head of the department, that I try to set up a research program
were there would be no opportunity for staff to feel that the department head was using his authority to take funds ahead of somebody else who needed them, you see.
And when I first started this program,
At the laying hens, my research with laying hens has majorly been designed in the applied or practical kind of areas rather than in the highly basic or scientific areas.
And this is also purposely set up because

At the time the program started, the income from the sale of surplus eggs from the experiments was that the price of eggs was generally high enough to pay for the feed, the labor, and so that actually the research program of the laying hens was self-supporting.
And therefore, I could use the sales returns from the research program and feel free of not being misunderstood in terms of priorities, administrative priorities, for the research program.
And so that is the reason why this was picked.
In the case of broilers, if the price of broilers was high at the time you marketed your birds, then you probably got some returns.
But if, on the other hand, it was low, you might have lost some money.
But at that time, laying hands, now it happens that actually the price of eggs in the meantime have changed so that currently you'd be subject to the same danger.
that you would withdraw this.
But in those days, it was not so, and this determined two things.

That I would pick laying hens for my experimental program, and that I'd pick the productive, applied efficiency areas, management and so on, those areas of research, rather than the costly, basic type of research.
That way you would leave the funds appropriated by the state for the other members of the department.
Yes, yes.
And I was very careful for them to see the budgets as the appropriations were made each year, and also for them to see what they had available for their programs.
And I think, as far as I know, I did not have complaints.
I might not have ever heard them, if there's been any.
But I was real proud of the fact that I overheard little and no complaints because of this.
And it was done purposely for this reason.
You mentioned just a minute ago about for a long time eggs were kind of a steady cash crop, but now the price tends to fluctuate more than it did in the past.
Yes, and not only that, but the margins, the egg production units have become so large.
There used to be a fairly large margin between the cost of production and the sale price of the eggs.
But now, because the units have gotten so bignow, I don't know which is cause and which iswell, I do, too, but it could be rationalized which is cause and which is effect.
But the units are so large today that they have to be that way because the margins have gotten so narrow between the actual production cost price
cost and the sale price of the eggs.
And for that reason, there isn't much margin left there.
And so you're very close to the same kind of a fluctuating pattern that we have in broilers.
During your tenure as head of the department, how were your research projects chosen?
Did you see a problem and try to solve it, or did you have an interest and follow the interest?
Well, of course it was a combination of both because none of us like to do work that we don't like ourselves.
But here I mentioned when we first started this area of discussion, I mentioned that here might be an area where an individual could boast a little bit.
Well, here's what I did.

I have religiously and many times, partly if not wholly at my own expense, I have attended national and international meetings to keep up with what the problems were in this country domestically, in the various states, and in the various countries of the world, what problems were bothering
the and troubling the production group and so i was able by this method to keep up with these and in a few cases i hope that intuitively i anticipated what was coming next
And so for this reason, we tried to get the answers at least by the time they were needed, and in a few cases, ahead of that.
I think in one particular case, in the matter of phase fading, we had some answers before industry was ready to adopt it.
And as a result, it didn't get much attention for quite a long while.
Okay.
I noted that in the past you had had several occasions on which you had a foreign assignment.
Could you talk about those for a little bit?
Yes, I was very fortunate in making some of the foreign meetings, as I said, part of them at my own expense and part of them at the invitation of the particular governments
that were involved, and the major source of funds for the foreign trips was AID assignments, and so I participated always on a short-term basis, because I could not afford to be gone very long.
But these have always been quite attractive to me,
I like to travel.
I love to meet and get to know people in other countries and to see their problems as well as our own.
And back to our research program, here's another one that we might have anticipated a little bit because when I came back
from hawaii most of the birds in hawaii this was not necessarily intuitive but purely an observation that in hawaii most of the birds were housed laying birds were housed in cages
And almost no birds in Texas at that time were housed in cages.
There were quite a few in California, but none in Texas.
So we initiated, immediately initiated, a cage-laying experiment and started getting together data on the feeding of cage-layers and the management of cage-layers.
And so now almost 100% of the birds in some of the states are housed in cages, and a very high percentage
of the lame birds in Texas are now housed in cages as well.
But at first, some of those early reports were not always accepted as friendlily as I would like for them to have been, but they were, and so for that reason, we believe that
THIS ENTERED IN TO THE
availability for some of the foreign assignments.
By caged layers, you mean is each chicken in an individual cage?
At first they majorly were housed this way, but very quickly they, and a lot of the work was done here that showed that it could be done otherwise.
The cost of building a cage
for one bird is fairly high.
So what they did, they started putting what we call higher density.
In other words, we put two birds per cage, three birds per cage.
In a few cases, the cages would be a little bigger in size.
But the density, the square footage of the cage area allowed per bird was reduced as we added more birds.
And so the common practice now is to house from three to five birds per cage per unit.
And you get more eggs at less cost in this method than by letting the birds run free?
If they're properly managed.
They have to be de-beaked, keep them picking each other.
They have to be properly fed.
And the diets have been increased in density because there is more competition between birds.
There's both social competition between birds, and there's also mechanical competition for water and feeder space.

And so if they're properly managed, and all of this had to be investigated experimentally in order to supply industry with some of the answers to some of the questions and solutions to some of the problems they had in doing this.
And generally, there's been the initiation of the POTI programs in many of the foreign countries because of the...
availability of labor.
See, labor's been cheap in most of the developing countries.
And the cage operation at first, at least, it's become so mechanized now that it may not any longer be true in this country.
But the labor required for cage operation was a little higher than the litter floor kind of operation.
And so it just
it became natural to recommend cage operations in these foreign countries.
And this led to, as you went from one to another, this led to assignments in the various countries.
But in view of the fact that you were head of the very active department here on campus,
it was not possible for you to really take a long-term assignment.
Right.
The longest assignment that I ever took was six weeks.
And these were usually taken in the middle of a semester.
rarely, I don't believe ever, at budget-making time or at the beginning of the semesters.
It was usually, they were flexible.
These assignments were flexible, and they usually were taken when the time could be spared.
And we had some very excellent people on the staff who assumed responsibility for the mechanical work of the department head while I was gone.
Now that you've reached retirement age and
I believe you told me earlier that you had finished with all of the students who were working under you at the time of your retirement.
Do you look forward to perhaps a longer stint abroad someplace in the future?
No, I just don't like to be gone.
I want to keep up with the United States, with my friends and the industry and the progress of the industry in the United States.
And so I have limited my assignments, longer than the six weeks, but I've limited my assignments to three.
Perhaps I might be able to take three and a half or four months, but I've limited to that.
If an assignment is longer than this, I think it would be no problem to get a two-year assignment, but I will not accept a two-year assignment anywhere.
The maximum was the one that I've had so far is the one I had this year.
early this year, the latter part of last year, December, January, and February, the three months in Pakistan.
And there may be some others.
I can take up to three months now, but I do not plan to take much longer than this length of assignment.
Again, it takes you too far away from your contacts locally.
Yes, yes.
My ideas are so small and so few that it doesn't take me much more than three months to get a whole express worked out.
So for that reason, the longer assignments, you actually may be getting into the mechanics rather than to idea development.
Well, it's the type of thing you do.
I take it as more giving of advice rather than going in and setting up a totally new program.
Yeah, generally this is true, yes.
It's really, they are, I think all of the assignments I've had could very well be called consultantships.
Now, there were AIDA consultantships.
There were, in some cases, private industry consultantships.
I've been invited to go to some of the countries by private industry for consultation.
And in other cases, it's been...

for the government itself in these countries, consultant with the government officials as to how to design the program, whether they should try to breed their own birds, or whether they should import the breeding stock from other countries and establish a franchise kind of a breeding program, and this type of information is major.
The last assignment I spoke of in Pakistan was an FAO, United Nations assignment.
That was my first United Nations assignment, incidentally.

But the type of assignment that you have been accepting can be handled in the short term, whereas if you were to go into a developing country that had not had a poultry science department and they wanted to establish one,
And they chose you to do that.
That's the kind that would take a long time.
Yes, that would take a long time.
And I have not desired and have not accepted responsibility for that type of an assignment.
Are you continuing to carry on individual research at the current time?
Yes, on a bit of a limited basis.
A great deal of my research program was carried on by the graduate students.
finishing up of the graduate students, well then this means that I either have to have a technician kind of help or I have to depend upon personally doing the work myself and the
labor that is not trained in this area and has no particular concern about the specific requirements of a research program, and for that reason the experiments of that sort
I'm not willing to design the experiments and have to throw the data away when I get it accumulated.
If you decide you're going to feed a chicken a certain number of grams of the kind of food per day, it has to be exactly that many.
A few too many would not matter so much to someone who is not working on a degree in that area.
But if a student is working on a degree, then he's going to be very careful if he doesn't write.
I've had some very fine graduate students in the past, and it's been a real pleasure to work with them.
They've been quite exacting.
and quite careful in their program of work.
And it's naturally mutual because they, most of them, have been establishing a learning and establishing a program of activity to be continued post graduation for them and so naturally they want to
to do a good job.
And so as a result, it's been dependable.
I could depend upon it myself, and the material could be published or used, distributed to industry with a confidence that otherwise might not be there.
I believe you have received a number of honors or awards during your
tenure here, are any of those that particularly stand out in your mind as those which, in a sense, you might have appreciated the most of all?
Well, it's been my privilege to serve and
capacities within the organization, the honor societies and the technical organizations to which I belonged.
And this has always been a real challenge and a real reward when it's finished in that regard.
But there are certain awards that I have received and for which I'm very grateful and which have been a source of encouragement to me.
Perhaps just to mention a few of those, one would be the...
the research, the former students distinguished faculty achievement award.
And mine was in the area of research.
And I very much appreciated this.
And it's been a real challenge, a real encouragement for further achievement.
And then from industry, that would be from the university, from the industry there are two things that stand out in my mind.
One is that the American Poultry and Hatchery Federation, which has now been merged with the Institute of American Poultry Industries,
asked me to serve as their research director and they had about fifteen to twenty thousand dollars a year that they wanted to put in institutional research
programs.

And so it is my business to accumulate research projects from the Pony scientists in the various land grant, mostly land grant, but there were other types of institutions, assemble those during the year, digest them, and then turn them over to the research committee, three of these industry members, and they pick then the particular projects that were to be supported for the following year, and then a small grant.
The grants were purposely small because they wanted to distribute them widely to encourage research in the areas in which they were having problems.
And you asked a moment ago about how we figured out these problems.
Well, this helped.
I served for about nine years.
They called it the research director of APHL.
And I have a plaque commemorating this service, but it was a very delightful kind of experience.
And then the other was the receipt of the second Golden Feather Award, which was made by our Texas Poetry Federation in the state.
This was made in 1969.
And it's right there behind you.
And I'm very extremely proud of that.
Another one of our faculty members, Mr. Ben Warmly, who is retired, received the seventh one just about three weeks ago at Dallas at the Texas Polar Federation meeting.
They give only one of those per year.
One per year, right.
So it must be rather a high honor to receive
something of that nature.
Well, naturally, those of us who received it consider it so.
We could be prejudiced.
I would be.
Well, I think anytime when you're the only one in the entire state of Texas, and I imagine the Poultry Federation is a sizable group.
It represents all of the commodity areas.
There's five different sections within it.
There is the hatchery group, there is the broiler group, there's the egg group, there is the Allied Poultry Association, all of those who sell vaccines, equipment, etc.
That's the Allied Poultry Group.
And then the egg production, egg producers, and I think that's the hatchery, the egg, the broiler, the turkey, yes, the Texas Turkey Federation group.
So those are all part of the Mother Hubbard organization, which is called the Texas Poetry Federation.
And the award is made by the federation, which represents all of those groups.
Oh, gracious Jesus.
